column1: Temuco (Spanish pronunciation: [teˈmuko]) is a city and commune
column2: capital of the Cautín Province and of the Araucanía Region in southern Chile. The city is located 670 kilometres (416 miles) south of Santiago .

column1: Temuco's central place in Araucanía with easy access to the Andean valleys
column2: lakes and coastal areas makes it a hub for tourism
column3: agricultural
column4: livestock and forestry operations as well as a communication and trade centre for the numerous small towns of Araucanía. Temuco has recently been regarded as a university city as it houses two large universities: University of the Frontier and Temuco Catholic University. Nobel laureates Gabriela Mistral and Pablo Neruda both lived in Temuco for some time.

column1: The word Temuco comes from the Mapudungun language
column2: meaning "temu water"; "temu" is the common name of two native trees of the family Myrtaceae
column3: Luma apiculata (also known as arrayán in Spanish) and Blepharocalyx cruckschankii. Both species are characterized by their orange-reddish bark and by having aromatic fruits and leaves which are commonly used by the Mapuche for medicinal purposes. While Blepharocalyx cruckschankii is endangered
column4: Luma apiculata is relatively common and in Temuco it is possible to see it in the Cerro Ñielol Natural Monument (in its natural state) as well as in city gardens and sidewalks. The blend between the words "temu" and "co" (water)
column5: probably reflects the fact that these trees frequently grow beside water bodies.

column1: Chilean poetry has deep roots in Temuco. Nobel laureates Gabriela Mistral and Pablo Neruda (Neftalí Reyes) both lived in Temuco. Mistral was the principal of an all-girls school where Neruda would visit her and show her his first verses when he was around 15 years old.
In 2010 Temuco was affected by the earthquake on February 27 centered 400 km (250 mi) to the north. It was one of the most affected regions of Chile besides Santiago
column2: Concepcion
column3: Valparaíso and others. The earthquake registered 8.8 Mw on the moment magnitude scale. Though landlocked Temuco avoided the tsunamis the earthquake caused
column4: many very strong aftershocks throughout the country followed
column5: including a 7.1 MW earthquake 70 km (43 mi) northwest of the city.

column1: Temuco is located in a valley in the center-south of Chile
column2: equidistant between the Pacific Ocean to the west and the Andes to the east. Morphologically
column3: the city placement corresponds to Cautín River-originated fluvial land masses that developed in a crushed form between two hills

column1: The city is surrounded by a landscape typical to central-southern Chile
column2: consisting mostly of plantations of exotic species used in forestry along with prairies. The original ecosystem of the area consisting in temperate forest is present mostly in the Ñielol hill. Given that burning wood is the primary source of heat during the cold months in Temuco
column3: air pollution is a recurrent problem during autumn and winter. As a consequence
column4: Air quality in Temuco is the third lowest in Chile.

column2: Temuco lies at the border of Chile's central valley Mediterranean region
column3: albeit with an oceanic climate (Köppen climate classification: Cfb ). Through the year
column5: with a distinct drier summer period (although not as dry as Santiago or other central valley cities
column6: receiving just enough precipitation to avoid a Mediterranean climate classification). Its mean annual temperature is 13 °C (55 °F)
column7: with highest median during the warmest month of 23.5 °C (74 °F) and lowest median during the coldest month of 3.5 °C (38 °F) (Ciren-Corfo
column8: 1992). Annual mean rain during 1961-1990 (Dirección Meteorológica de Chile
column10: 157 millimetres (45.6 in) (Capelli de Steffens et al.

column2: Temuco is a third-level administrative division of Chile administered by a municipal council
column3: headed by an alcalde who is directly elected every four years. The 2008-2012 alcalde is Miguel Becker Alvear (RN).Within the electoral divisions of Chile
column4: Temuco is represented in the Chamber of Deputies by Germán Becker (RN) and René Saffirio (PDC) as part of the 50th electoral district
column5: (together with Padre Las Casas). The commune is represented in the Senate by José Garcia Ruminot (RN) and Eugenio Tuma Zedan (PPD) as part of the 15th senatorial constituency (Araucanía-South).

Temuco was also one of the host cities of the official 1959 Basketball World Cup
column2: where Chile won the bronze medal.
Temuco has numerous gyms and parks where people can go on their leisure time.

column1: Buses and collective taxis are the most popular modes of mass transit. The bus fare is CLP$150 for students and $450 for adults; the colectivos charge $500 ($650 at night).  Regular taxis are also available.
La Araucanía Airport is commercial air terminal for Temuco located to the south of the city
column2: near the town of Freire
column3: about 20 minutes south of Temuco.

column1: The railroad connects Temuco with Victoria to the north and points in between.
Temuco does not have a rapid transit rail system.
Long-haul buses run from the Terminal Rodoviario de la Araucania [3]
column2: at the northern approach to town.

column1: Private transport by car is commonly used which causes traffic congestion at peak hours.
The recent proliferation of bike lanes has placed transportation by bicycle as an emerging trend. By 2017
column2: 35 km of bike lanes are expected to be operative.[4]

column1: Cerro ÑielolThe Ñielol Hill houses the original temperate forest at this latitude in southern Chile as it was before the Spanish people colonised it. Currently
column2: it has the status of natural monument and as such
column3: it is a protected area. It has also a special meaning for the Mapuche people living in the Region
column4: housing near the top a ceremonial area called La Patagua. We can also find a restaurant at the top of the Hill and a viewpoint of the east side of the city and Padre Las Casas
column5: across the river. It is easily accessed by foot or car. The Southern Andean Volcano Observatory has its office there.

column1: Central marketThe central market is one of the best places to get Mapuche crafts. It has a meat market and shops selling woodcrafts
column2: artifacts
column3: wool knits
column4: and similar goods. A fire has recently affected its structure. Reconstruction is planned
column5: but the original market is currently closed.

column1: One of the most traditional places in the city. Fresh fruits and vegetables are sold here in a daily basis. People from the city and from rural nearby towns come here for trade.
Alemania AvenueIs the principal artery in Temuco. Here we can find The Araucaria Museum building (19th century Chilean style); the Menchaca Lira Campus of Art Building (a Victorian Style building
column2: recently restored); The English Alley
column3: where we can find the Red Cross Building and not long ago a blue house which was dismantled to be rebuilt elsewhere (as a Heritage recovery project by the school of architecture of a known University of Temuco)

column2: Alemania Av. has become an important commercial centre. Several restaurants
column3: night clubs
column9: supermarkets and two shopping malls have been opened there. There is also a Casino and a five stars hotel in the same avenue.

column1: Anibal Pinto SquareThe core of Downtown Temuco is the Main Square Anibal Pinto. Temuco's Main Square is the only one in Chile that was not built with a water fountain in its centre; an art gallery was built in 1981 as part of a total renewal. Compared to other main squares of southern Chile
column2: Temuco's looks very modern. It was named one of Chile's most beautiful plazas.
